Children: 2{{cite web|url=http://www.christianpost.com/news/american-sniper-widow-recalls-heartbreaking-moment-kids-learned-navy-seal-dad-chris-kyle-had-been-killed-132770/|title='American Sniper' Widow Recalls Heartbreaking Moment Kids Learned Navy SEAL Dad Chris Kyle Had Been Killed|work=Christian Post|accessdate=January 30, 2015}} | spouse = {{marriage|[[Taya Kyle]]|2002}}{{cite web|url=http://www.cemetery.state.tx.us/pub/user_form.asp?pers_id=11781|title=Taya Renae Kyle profile|publisher=Cemetery.state.tx.us|accessdate=July 22, 2013}} | laterwork = ''[[American Sniper (book)|American Sniper]]'' (2012)
''American Gun'' (2013){{cite book|title=American Gun|date=June 2013|publisher=HarperCollins|authors=Kyle, Chris & Doyle, William |url=https://m.harpercollins.com/9780062242716/american-gun}} | signature = }} '''Christopher Scott''' "'''Chris'''" '''Kyle''' (April 8, 1974 − February 2, 2013) was a [[United States Navy SEAL]] veteran and sniper. Kyle served four tours in the [[Iraq War]] and was awarded several commendations for acts of heroism and meritorious service in combat. He was awarded one [[Silver Star Medal]], four [[Bronze Star Medal]]s with [["V" device]]s, a Navy and Marine Corps [[Achievement Medal]] and numerous other unit and personal awards.{{cite web|last1=Brook|first1=Tom Vanden|title=Navy lowers medal count for SEAL Chris Kyle|url=http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2016/07/08/navy-lowers-medal-count-seal-chris-kyle/86468402/|work=USA Today|accessdate=July 9, 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160708215219/http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2016/07/08/navy-lowers-medal-count-seal-chris-kyle/86468402/|archivedate=July 8, 2016|date=July 8, 2016|dead-url=no}} Kyle was [[honorably discharged]] from the U.S. Navy in 2009 and published his bestselling autobiography, ''[[American Sniper (book)|American Sniper]]'', in 2012. An [[American Sniper|eponymous film adaptation]] of Kyle's book, directed by [[Clint Eastwood]], was released two years later. On February 2, 2013, Kyle was murdered by Eddie Ray Routh at a shooting range near [[Chalk Mountain, Texas]].{{cite news|last1=Lamothe|first1=Dan|title=The fatal intersection of Navy SEAL Chris Kyle and the Marine veteran who killed him|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/news/checkpoint/wp/2015/02/13/first-days-of-american-sniper-murder-trial-leave-questions-unanswered/|accessdate=January 14, 2016|work=[[The Washington Post]]|date=February 13, 2015}} A former Marine with PTSD, Routh was found guilty and sentenced to life in prison without parole.{{cite news|url=http://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-news/news/eddie-ray-routh-found-guilty-in-death-of-american-snipers-chris-kyle-2015252 |title= Eddie Ray Routh Found Guilty of Murder in Shooting Death of American Sniper's Chris Kyle|work=Us Weekly |author=Madeline Boardman |date=February 25, 2015 |accessdate=March 10, 2015 }} ==Early life== Kyle was born in [[Odessa, Texas]], the first of two boys born to Deby Lynn ([[Name at birth|née]] Mercer) and Wayne Kenneth Kyle, a [[Sunday school]] teacher and [[deacon]].{{cite web|url=https://familysearch.org/ark:/61903/1:1:V8KW-VP1|title=Christopher Scott Kyle, Texas, Birth Index, 1903-1997|publisher=[[FamilySearch]]|accessdate=January 4, 2015}} Kyle's father bought his son his first rifle at 8 years old, a bolt-action [[.30-06 Springfield]] rifle, and later a shotgun, with which they hunted deer, [[pheasant]], and [[quail]].{{cite news|url=http://www.nypost.com/p/news/national/meet_the_big_shot_BxlVpxzQijkC9mwZcmwkrN?utm_source=SFnewyorkpost&utm_medium=SFnewyorkpost|title=Meet the big shot – SEAL is America's deadliest sniper|author=Buiso, Gray|date=January 1, 2012|accessdate=January 3, 2012|work=New York Post}} Kyle and his brother grew up raising up to 150 head of cattle at a time.{{cite web|url=http://www.pbr.com/en/news/features/other-features/2014/1/pbr-legends-ross-coleman-and-luke-snyder-assisting-with-chris-kyle-memorial-roping-auction.aspx|title=CHRIS KYLE HAD A LOVE FOR THE COWBOY LIFESTYLE|work=Professional Bull Riders|date=January 29, 2014|accessdate=May 28, 2016|first=Keith Ryan|last=Cartwright}} Kyle attended high school in [[Midlothian, Texas]],{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=h2Op0C9hXA0C&pg=PT13&lpg=PT13&dq=chris+kyle+high+school+football&source=bl&ots=l4E_k-ST4r&sig=MFx-x6eEGGK6QXInraVJ5h01KWs&hl=en&sa=X&ei=wQ24VJSAO4apyQSjsYGAAg&ved=0CDYQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=chris%20kyle%20high%20school%20football&f=false|title=The Life and Legend of Chris Kyle: American Sniper, Navy SEAL|accessdate=January 30, 2015}} and after graduating, became a professional [[bronco]] rodeo rider and ranch hand, but his professional rodeo career ended abruptly when he severely injured his arm.{{cite web|url=http://www.military.com/special-operations/special-operations-forces-veteran-chris-kyle.html |title=Special Operations Forces Profile: Chris Kyle|publisher=Military.com |accessdate=March 10, 2015 }} ==Military career== After his arm healed, Kyle went to a military recruiting office, interested in joining the [[United States Marine Corps|U.S. Marine Corps]] [[special operations]]. A [[United States Navy|U.S. Navy]] recruiter convinced him to try, instead, for the [[United States Navy SEALs|SEALs]]. Initially, Kyle was rejected because of the [[Internal fixation|pins in his arm]], but he eventually received an invitation to the 24-week [[United States Navy SEAL selection and training#Basic Underwater Demolition/SEAL (BUD/S) Training (24 weeks)|Basic Underwater Demolition SEAL school (BUDS)]], which he joined in 1999. Assigned to [[SEAL Team 3]], sniper element, platoon "Charlie" (later "Cadillac"),{{cite book|author1=Kyle, Chris |author2=McEwen, Scott |author3=DeFelice, Chris |title=American Sniper|publisher=Harper Collins|date=February 5, 2012|ISBN=0-06-208235-3}} within the [[United States Naval Special Warfare Command|Naval Special Warfare Command]], and with four tours of duty, Kyle served in many major battles of the Iraq War. His first long-range kill shot was taken during the initial invasion when he shot a woman approaching a group of Marines while carrying a hand grenade. CNN reported that the woman was cradling a toddler in her other hand.{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2013/02/03/us/texas-sniper-killed-kyle-profile/index.html |title = 'Chris Kyle, America's deadliest sniper, offered no regrets' |date=February 5, 2013|accessdate=January 1, 2015}} As ordered, Kyle opened fire, killing the woman before she could attack.{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/usa/8990552/The-Devil-of-Rahmadi-named-Americas-deadliest-sniper.html|title='The Devil of Ramadi' named America's deadliest sniper|author=Sanchez, Raf|work=The Daily Telegraph|date=January 2, 2012|accessdate=January 2, 2012|location=London}} He later stated, "the woman was already dead. I was just making sure she didn't take any Marines with her. It was clear that not only did she want to kill them, but she didn’t care about anybody else nearby who would have been blown up by the grenade or killed in the firefight. Children on the street, people in the houses, maybe her child." Because of his track record as a marksman during his deployment to [[Ramadi]], the insurgents named Kyle ''Shaitan Ar-Ramadi'' (English: "The Devil of Ramadi"), and put a $21,000 bounty on his head that was later increased to $80,000. They posted signs highlighting the cross on his arm as a means of identifying him. In his book, ''American Sniper'', Kyle describes his longest successful shot: in 2008, outside [[Sadr City]], he killed an insurgent sniper aiming at other members of the US military with "a straight-up luck shot" from his [[McMillan Tac-50|McMillan Tac-338]] sniper rifle from about {{convert|2,100|yd|m|0}} away. Kyle became known as "The Legend" among the general infantry and Marines he was tasked to protect. The nickname originated among Kyle's fellow SEALs following his taking of a sabbatical to train other snipers in [[Fallujah]], and he was sometimes called "The Myth".{{cite book|author=Kyle, Chris|title=American Sniper|publisher=HarperCollins|date=2012}} During four tours of duty in the Iraq War, he was shot twice and survived six separate [[Improvised explosive device|IED]] detonations. ===Number of kills as a sniper=== While the Navy, Pentagon, and [[U.S. Special Operations Command]]s (SOC) have not challenged the claim that Kyle was the current top sniper, his exact number of sniper kills is obscure. To be counted as confirmed, "They basically had to see the person fall and be clearly dead", according to [[Jim DeFelice]], one of the coauthors of Kyle's autobiography.{{cite news|last1=Briggs |first1=Bill |title=Confirmed kills: A solemn secret for military snipers is becoming a pop-culture hit |url=http://usnews.nbcnews.com/_news/2013/07/30/19679964-confirmed-kills-a-solemn-secret-for-military-snipers-is-becoming-a-pop-culture-hit? |accessdate=September 5, 2014 |publisher=NBC News |date=July 30, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130902113212/http://usnews.nbcnews.com/_news/2013/07/30/19679964-confirmed-kills-a-solemn-secret-for-military-snipers-is-becoming-a-pop-culture-hit? |archivedate=September 2, 2013 }} Kyle's shooter's statements (shooter's statements are filled out by every sniper after a mission) were reported to higher command, who kept them in case any kill were contested as outside the [[Rules of Engagement|rules of engagement]] (ROE). The publisher [[HarperCollins]] states: "The Pentagon has officially confirmed more than 150 of Kyle's kills (the previous American record was 109), but it has declined to verify the astonishing total number for this book."{{cite web|title=About The Book|url=http://harpercollins.com/books/American-Sniper/?isbn=9780062082350|work=American Sniper: The Autobiography of the Most Lethal Sniper in U.S. Military History|publisher=HarperCollins|accessdate=June 22, 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120111232749/http://www.harpercollins.com/books/American-Sniper/?isbn=9780062082350 |archivedate=January 11, 2012}} In his autobiography, Kyle wrote:
"The Navy credits me with more kills as a sniper than any other American service member, past or present. I guess that's true. They go back and forth on what the number is. One week, it's 160 (the 'official' number as of this writing, for what that's worth), then it's way higher, then it's somewhere in between. If you want a number, ask the Navy—you may even get the truth if you catch them on the right day."{{cite news|url=http://www.thehistoryreader.com/military-history/chris-kyle-al-shaitan-iraq/|title=Chris Kyle: al-Shaitan of Iraq|date=March 14, 2012|accessdate=February 13, 2013}}
On July 8, 2016, the U.S. Navy corrected Kyle's [[DD Form 214]] regarding some decorations listed on his original discharge document.{{cite news|last=Crawford|first=Jamie|publisher=CNN|title=Navy: 'American Sniper' medal count corrected|accessdate=August 17, 2016}} The original discharge papers issued to him upon leaving the service (a DD-214) tally with his account given in his autobiography, of two Silver Stars and five Bronze Stars with valor. The Navy revised it to one Silver Star and four Bronze Stars with valor. The Navy said "Kyle would have played no role in the production of his personnel files other than signing the DD-214 upon his discharge" and "[a]fter thoroughly reviewing all available records, the Navy determined an error was made" and "issued a corrected copy of the DD214, which accurately reflects Kyle's years of honorable and extraordinary service." ===Weapons=== As a sniper, Kyle was often asked about his weapons. While in training, he used four different rifles in order to know which weapon was the most useful in the given situation. In the field, he used the following: * a semi-automatic [[SR-25|7.62 NATO Mk 11]] sniper rifle (patrol) * a [[Mk 12 Special Purpose Rifle|5.56 NATO Mk 12 Designated Marksman Rifle]] modified with the lower receiver off a [[M4 carbine|M-4]] to get a collapsible stock and allow full auto (for urban patrol) * a [[M24 Sniper Weapon System#M24A2|.300 Winchester Magnum M24]] sniper rifle with MacMillan stocks and customized barrels, later replaced with a [[Accuracy International AWM|.300 Winchester Magnum Accuracy International]]. These two rifles were the ones he mostly used while in overwatch.{{clarify|date=December 2015}} *a [[.338 Lapua Magnum]] used for Long Range Targets ==Post-military life== [[File:Taya Kyle 1.jpg|thumb|upright|float|left|[[Taya Kyle]] in August 2013]] Kyle left the U.S. Navy in 2009 and moved to [[Midlothian, Texas]], with his wife, Taya, and two children.{{cite web|url=http://www.harpercollins.com/books/American-Sniper/?isbn=9780062082350|title=American Sniper|author1=Kyle, Chris |author2=McEwen, Scott |author3=DeFelice, Chris |publisher=Harper Collins|date=January 2, 2012|accessdate=January 2, 2012}} He was president of Craft International, a tactical training company for the U.S. military and law enforcement communities.{{cite web|url=http://webarchiveproject.org/10904/|title=Craft International|accessdate=August 10, 2012}} In 2012, [[HarperCollins]] released Kyle's autobiography, ''[[American Sniper (book)|American Sniper]]''. Kyle had initially hesitated to write the book but was persuaded to move forward because other books about SEALs were underway.{{cite news|last1=Fernandez and Michael Schwirtz|first1=Manny|title=Untouchable in Iraq, Ex-Sniper Dies in a Shooting Back Home|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2013/02/04/us/chris-kyle-american-sniper-author-reported-killed.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0|accessdate=January 14, 2015|work=The New York Times|date=February 3, 2013}} In his book, Kyle wrote bluntly of his experiences. Of the battle for control of Ramadi he says: "Force moved that battle. We killed the bad guys and brought the leaders to the peace table. That is how the world works."{{cite news|last1=Perry|first1=Scott|title=Book review: 'American Sniper: The Autobiography of the Most Lethal Sniper in U.S. Military History' by Chris Kyle, Scott McEwen and Jim DeFelice|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2012/mar/05/entertainment/la-et-book-20120305|accessdate=January 14, 2015|work=Los Angeles Times|date=March 5, 2012}} In the book and ensuing interviews, Kyle stated he had no regrets about his work as a sharpshooter, saying, "I had to do it to protect the Marines."{{cite news|last1=Botelho|first1=Greg, Joe Johns and Ted Metzger|title=Police: Man accused of killing ex-SEAL said he had PTSD, was hurting|url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/02/04/justice/texas-sniper-killed/|accessdate=January 14, 2015|work=CNN|publisher=CNN.com|date=February 5, 2013}} ''American Sniper'' had a 37-week run on ''[[The New York Times]]'' bestseller list and brought Kyle national attention.{{cite news|last1=Pulliam Bailey|first1=Sarah|title=Here's the faith in the 'American Sniper' you won't see in the film|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/national/religion/heres-the-faith-in-the-american-sniper-you-wont-see-in-the-film/2015/01/14/f7c33bd6-9c0a-11e4-86a3-1b56f64925f6_story.html|accessdate=January 14, 2015|work=The Washington Post|date=January 14, 2014}} Following its release, media articles challenged some of Kyle's anecdotes,{{cite news|last1=LaMothe|first1=Dan|title=Jesse Ventura vs. Chris Kyle: A case where no one won|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/news/checkpoint/wp/2014/07/30/jesse-ventura-vs-chris-kyle-a-case-where-no-one-won/|accessdate=January 14, 2016|work=The Washington Post|date=July 30, 2014}} but the core of his narrative was widely accepted. "Tales of his heroism on the battlefield were already lore in every branch of the armed forces", writes Michael J. Mooney, author of a biography of Kyle.{{cite news|last1=Hoinski|first1=Michael|title=The Controversial True Story Behind 'American Sniper'|url=http://www.mensjournal.com/adventure/collection/the-controversial-true-story-behind-american-sniper-20141222#ixzz3OpQ9DrL4|accessdate=January 14, 2015|work=Men's Journal Magazine|date=December 22, 2014}} Kyle paired with FITCO Cares Foundation, a nonprofit organization which created the Heroes Project to provide free in-home fitness equipment, individualized programs, personal training, and life-coaching to in-need veterans with disabilities, [[Gold Star Families for Peace|Gold Star families]], or those suffering from [[posttraumatic stress disorder]] (PTSD).{{cite web|url=http://www.fitcocares.org|title=Fitco Cares|publisher=Fitcocares.org|accessdate=August 10, 2012}} On August 13, 2012, Kyle appeared on the [[reality television]] show ''[[Stars Earn Stripes]]'', which features celebrities pairing up with a special operations or law enforcement professional who train them in weapons and combat tactics. Kyle was teamed with actor [[Dean Cain]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nbc.com/stars-earn-stripes/about/bios/chris-kyle|title=Stars Earn Stripes Bio for Chris Kyle|publisher=Nbc.com|accessdate=September 8, 2012}} ===Defamation lawsuit=== In Kyle's book ''American Sniper'', Kyle wrote a subchapter titled "Punching Out Scruff Face" about an alleged altercation in a bar. In the book he claims he punched a man he refers to as "Scruff" who told Kyle, "You deserve to lose a few." Kyle later identified Scruff Face as [[Jesse Ventura]] in interviews he did to promote the book.{{cite news|last1=Staff|title=Court tosses out Jesse Ventura's $1.8mn verdict against 'American Sniper'|url=https://www.rt.com/usa/346547-ventura-american-sniper-award/|accessdate=June 13, 2016|work=RT International|agency=Associated Press|publisher=TV-Novosti|date=June 13, 2016|language=en-EN}} According to Kyle, the encounter took place at McP's, a bar in [[Coronado, California]], on October 12, 2006, during a [[Wake (ceremony)|wake]] for Kyle's comrade, [[Michael A. Monsoor]], a U.S. Navy SEAL and [[Medal of Honor]] recipient who had been killed in Iraq.{{Cite book| title = American Sniper| last = Kyle| first = Chris| publisher = HarperCollins| year = 2012| isbn = 978-0062082350| location = |pages = }} On January 4, 2012, Kyle appeared on ''[[Opie and Anthony]]'' to discuss his book.''The Opie & Anthony Show.'' Sirius XM. January 4, 2012. Satellite Radio. On the show Kyle alleged that the character "Scruff" in his book is former Governor of Minnesota Jesse Ventura.{{cite web| url=http://www.theblaze.com/stories/2012/01/05/what-caused-a-navy-seal-to-punch-jesse-ventura-in-the-face/| title=Why Did the 'Deadliest' SEAL Sniper Punch Jesse Ventura in the Face?| author=Mike Opelka| work=The Blaze}}{{cite web| last1=Stern| first1=Mark Joseph| title=American Liar 38.3k 251 1.5k Why Jesse Ventura is likely to collect millions from Chris Kyle's American Sniper.| url=http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/jurisprudence/2015/01/american_sniper_lawsuit_chris_kyle_told_lies_about_jesse_ventura.html| website=Slate.com| publisher=The Slate Group LLC| accessdate=March 7, 2015}} Following these allegations, Ventura denied the incident had happened, and filed a lawsuit in January 2012 against Kyle for charges of [[United States defamation law|defamation]], [[Appropriation (law)|appropriation]], and unjust enrichment.{{cite news| last=Browning| first=Dan| title=Jesse Ventura aims to get even with Navy SEAL in court| url=http://www.startribune.com/local/140362163.html| work=[[Star Tribune]]| date=February 24, 2012| accessdate=June 9, 2013}}{{cite web| url=http://www.newyorker.com/news/news-desk/ventura-verdict| title=The Ventura Verdict| date=July 30, 2014| work=[[The New Yorker]] |accessdate=January 30, 2015}} After Kyle was killed the following year, Ventura continued the lawsuit against Kyle's estate.{{cite web| last=Chasmar| first=Jessica| title=Ex-Minn. Gov. Jesse Ventura sues Navy SEAL Chris Kyle's widow| url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2013/jun/2/ex-minn-gov-jesse-ventura-sues-navy-seal-chris-kyl| work=[[The Washington Times]]| date=June 2, 2013| accessdate=June 9, 2013}} On July 29, 2014, the jury returned a divided verdict of 8 to 2 that Kyle was guilty of defamation and unjust enrichment, and not guilty of appropriation. The jury concluded that the Kyle estate owed Ventura $500,000 for defamation, and $1.34 million for unjust enrichment.{{cite court |litigants=Jesse Ventura v. Chris Kyle |date=August 7, 2014 |court=District of Minnesota United States District Court |url=https://assets.documentcloud.org/documents/1268004/jesse-ventura-order.pdf |accessdate=April 12, 2016}}{{cite news| url=http://www.dallasnews.com/news/local-news/20140729-breaking-jury-awards-jesse-ventura-1.8-million-in-american-sniper-lawsuit.ece| title=Jury awards Jesse Ventura $1.8 million in 'American Sniper' lawsuit| work=[[The Dallas Morning News]]| date=July 29, 2014| accessdate=July 29, 2014}}{{cite news| title=Chris Kyle trial: Jesse Ventura wins $1.8 million in defamation case| url=http://www.oregonlive.com/lake-oswego/index.ssf/2014/07/chris_kyle_trial_jurors_warn_t.html| agency=[[Associated Press]]| work=[[The Oregonian]]| date=July 29, 2014| accessdate=April 12, 2016}} Kyle's widow appealed the verdict on behalf of Kyle's estate.{{cite news | url=http://www.mprnews.org/story/2014/12/23/american-sniper-appeal| title='American Sniper' widow to appeal Ventura defamation verdict| publisher=Mprnews.org| date=December 23, 2014 | accessdate=December 25, 2014}} Attorneys for Kyle's estate asked the appeals court to throw out the verdict or at least order a new trial, because a lawyer for Ventura told jurors that the $1.8 million judgment would be paid for by Kyle's book publisher's insurance policy, not his estate.{{cite news| work=Fox News Insider| url=http://insider.foxnews.com/2015/10/20/jesse-ventura-estate-american-sniper-chris-kyle-back-court-appeal| date=October 20, 2015| title=Here's Why Jesse Ventura Could Lose Lawsuit Against Chris Kyle's Estate on Appeal}} In June 2016, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 8th Circuit threw out the $1.8 million in part due to the revelation of the insurance policy by Ventura's attorneys to the jury. The $1.35 million in "unjust enrichment" was overturned and dismissed as being inconsistent with Minnesota law. The $500k defamation suit was remanded back to trial.{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/checkpoint/wp/2016/06/13/court-throws-out-1-8-million-judgment-against-american-sniper-chris-kyles-estate/|title=Court throws out $1.8 million judgment against ‘American Sniper’ Chris Kyle’s estate}}{{cite web|url=http://media.ca8.uscourts.gov/opndir/16/06/143876P.pdf|title=No. 14-3876}} ==Death== On February 2, 2013, Kyle and his friend, Chad Littlefield, 35, were shot and killed by Eddie Ray Routh at the Rough Creek Ranch-Lodge-Resort [[shooting range]] in [[Erath County, Texas]].{{cite web|title=Noted sniper slain at Erath County gun range|url=http://www.fox4news.com/story/20944143/decorated-war-hero-shot-and-killed-in-erath-county|publisher=[[KDFW|Fox4News]]|date=February 5, 2013|accessdate=March 10, 2015}} Both Kyle and Littlefield were armed with .45-caliber 1911-style pistols when they were killed, but neither gun had been unholstered or fired, and the safety catches were still on. Kyle was killed with a .45-caliber pistol, while Littlefield was shot with a 9mm [[SIG Sauer]] handgun. Both guns belonged to Kyle. Routh was a 25-year-old U.S. Marine Corps veteran from [[Lancaster, Texas]].{{cite web |last=Collins |first=Laura |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2892777/He-d-death-penalty-sit-bars-forever-Father-veteran-killed-American-Sniper-Chris-Kyle-tells-mourning-loss-son.html|title=Father of Chris Kyle killer Eddie Ray Routh is already mourning the loss of his son |date=February 2, 2013 |work=[[Daily Mail]] |accessdate=January 4, 2015}} Kyle and Littlefield had reportedly taken Routh to the gun range in an effort to help him with his [[post-traumatic stress disorder]] (PTSD). Routh had been in and out of mental hospitals for at least two years and had been diagnosed with [[schizophrenia]]. His family also said he suffered from PTSD from his time in the military.{{cite news |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2013/02/04/us/chris-kyle-american-sniper-author-reported-killed.html?_r=1& |title='American Sniper' Author Shot to Death in Texas |accessdate=February 3, 2013 |date=February 3, 2013 |newspaper=The New York Times |last=Schwirtz|first=Michael}}{{cite web|title=Man charged in fatal shooting of ex-SEAL/author|url=http://news.yahoo.com/man-charged-fatal-shooting-ex-seal-author-150201265.html |publisher=Yahoo! News |accessdate=February 3, 2013 |date=February 3, 2013}} On the way to the shooting range, Kyle texted Littlefield, "This dude is straight up nuts." Littlefield responded, "Watch my six", military slang meaning "watch my back".{{cite web|title=Chris Kyle's Widow Breaks Down on the Stand and the Chilling Text Message |work=ABC News |accessdate=June 14, 2014 |date=February 11, 2015 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pbjS6PuQbG4}} Four months later, while he was in his jail cell, Routh shared with former Erath County Sheriff's Deputy Gene Cole: "I was just riding in the back seat of the truck, and nobody would talk to me. They were just taking me to the range, so I shot them. I feel bad about it, but they wouldn't talk to me. I’m sure they've forgiven me." After the killings, Routh went to his sister's house in [[Midlothian, Texas|Midlothian]] and told her what he had done. His sister, Laura Blevins, called [[9-1-1]] and told the emergency operator: "They went out to a shooting range ... Like, he's all crazy. He's ... psychotic."{{cite book|title=The Enemy Within: The Inside Story of Eddie Routh, the Man Accused of Killing Legendary "American Sniper" Chris Kyle|first=Laura|last=Beil|publisher=Rodale |date=November 5, 2013}} Local police captured Routh after a short freeway chase, which ended when Routh, who fled the scene in Kyle's [[Ford F-350]] truck, crashed into a police cruiser in Lancaster.{{cite web |title=Author of 'American Sniper' among the dead at Rough Creek |url=http://www.yourstephenvilletx.com/news/local/article_01e35c44-6dab-11e2-a2e9-0019bb2963f4.html? |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130206103138/http://www.yourstephenvilletx.com/news/local/article_01e35c44-6dab-11e2-a2e9-0019bb2963f4.html? |archivedate=February 6, 2013 |date=February 2, 2013 |publisher=yourstephenvilletx.com |accessdate=February 3, 2013}} Routh was arraigned February 2, 2013, on two counts of [[capital murder]], and was taken to the Erath County Jail for holding under a $3 million bond.{{cite news |author=Copeland, Larry |url=http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2013/02/03/chris-kyle-navy-seal-dead/1887327 |title=Ex-SEAL Chris Kyle remembered after shooting death |date=February 3, 2013 |newspaper=USA Today}} His trial was set to begin May 5, 2014 but was delayed to allow more time to comply with DNA testing requirements.{{cite web |title=Chris Kyle Murder Trial Delayed |url=http://www.nbcdfw.com/news/local/Chris-Kyle-Murder-Trial-Delayed-257713261.html |work=Local News |date=May 2, 2014 |publisher=nbcdfw.com |accessdate=May 4, 2014}} The trial began on February 11, 2015.{{cite news |last1=Jervis|first1=Rick |title=At 'American Sniper' murder trial, a psychosis defense |url=http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2015/02/11/trial-chris-kyle-american-sniper-first-day/23197935/ |accessdate=February 12, 2015 |work=USA TODAY |date=February 12, 2015}} A memorial service was held for Kyle at [[Cowboys Stadium]] in [[Arlington, Texas]], on February 11, 2013. He was buried on February 12, 2013, at the [[Texas State Cemetery]] in [[Austin, Texas|Austin]], after the funeral cortege journeyed from Midlothian to Austin, more than {{convert|200|mi}}.{{cite web |url=http://www.nbcdfw.com/news/local/Thousands-Expected-for-Kyle-Procession-Tuesday-190770121.html |title=Chris Kyle Funeral Procession Arrives in Austin. NBC 5 Dallas-Fort Worth |publisher=Nbcdfw.com |date=February 12, 2013 |accessdate=July 15, 2014}} Hundreds of people lined [[Interstate 35]] to view the procession and pay their final respects to Kyle.{{cite web |url=http://thescoopblog.dallasnews.com/2013/02/details-announed-for-navy-seal-chris-kyles-memorial-service-at-cowboys-stadium.html/|title=Details announced for Navy SEAL Chris Kyle's memorial service at Cowboys Stadium|work=The Scoop Blog|accessdate=January 4, 2015}}{{cite web |url=http://www.kwtx.com/ourtown/communities/temple/headlines/Funeral-Procession-For-Slain-SEAL-Sniper-Will-Pass-Through-Central-Texas-190594921.html |title=Residents Line I-35 to Pay Respects to Slain Navy SEAL |date=February 12, 2013 |publisher=Kwtx.com |accessdate=January 4, 2015}} On February 24, 2015, Routh was found guilty of killing Kyle and Littlefield. The jury returned the verdict after less than three hours of deliberations. Since prosecutors decided beforehand not to seek the death penalty, the trial judge, Jason Cashon, immediately sentenced Routh to life in prison with no possibility of parole.{{cite news |last1=Kalthoff|first1=Ken |last2=Mone|first2=John L. |title=Jury Returns Guilty Verdict in 'American Sniper' Trial |url=http://www.nbcdfw.com/news/local/Closing-Arguments-Begin-in-Eddie-Ray-Routh-Murder-Trial-293918521.html |accessdate=February 25, 2015 |publisher= NBCUniversal Media |date=February 25, 2015}}{{cite news | url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/02/24/us/american-sniper-chris-kyle-trial/ | title=Jury finds Eddie Ray Routh guilty in 'American Sniper' case | publisher=CNN | date=February 24, 2015 | accessdate=February 24, 2015 | author=Ed Payne, Dana Ford and Jason Morris}} Routh is imprisoned at the [[Texas Department of Criminal Justice]] [[Powledge Unit]] near [[Palestine, Texas]].{{cite web|url=http://offender.tdcj.texas.gov/OffenderSearch/offenderDetail.action?sid=08977806 |title=Routh, Eddie Ray |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151227190257/http://offender.tdcj.texas.gov/OffenderSearch/offenderDetail.action?sid=08977806 |work=[[Texas Department of Criminal Justice]] |accessdate=December 28, 2015 |archivedate=December 27, 2015 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }} ==Legacy== [[File:Signing of Texas Chris Kyle Bill.jpg|thumb|float|The signing of the "Chris Kyle Bill" at the [[Texas State Capitol]] in August 2013]] In August 2013, Texas governor [[Rick Perry]] signed Senate Bill 162, also known as the "Chris Kyle Bill", to recognize military training in the issuance of [[Occupational licensing|occupational licenses]]. The bill had been co-sponsored by [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] Representative [[Dan Flynn (politician)|Dan Flynn]] of [[Van, Texas|Van]] and [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] Senator [[Leticia Van de Putte]] of [[San Antonio]]. The ceremony was attended by Kyle's widow Taya.{{cite web |url=http://www.dvidshub.net/news/113722/perry-signs-chris-kyle-bill-allows-military-experience-texas-state-licenses#.VMPtUkesVZs |title=Perry signs 'Chris Kyle Bill,' allows military experience for Texas state licenses|last1=Fountain |first1=Phil |date=August 28, 2013 |website=[[Defense Video & Imagery Distribution System]] |publisher=[[United States Department of Defense]] |accessdate=January 24, 2015}} Sculptor Greg Marra created a memorial statue of Kyle for presentation to his widow. Fundraising for production of the statue was provided by members of the [[Tea Party movement]].{{cite news |last=Lilley |first=Kevin |date=March 17, 2013 |title=Chris Kyle statue created for SEAL's widow |url=http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2013/03/17/chris-kyle-statue/1995555/ |newspaper=[[USA Today]] |accessdate=January 24, 2015}}{{cite news |last=Harper |first=Jennifer |date=November 10, 2013 |title=Tea party to honor fallen SEALs Chris Kyle, those at Benghazi with sculptures |url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2013/nov/10/to-seals-sculptor-spirits-of-heroes-are-still-aliv/?page=all |newspaper=[[The Washington Times]] |accessdate=January 24, 2015}} [[Clint Eastwood]]'s film ''[[American Sniper]]'' (2014) is based on Kyle's autobiography. Kyle is portrayed by [[Bradley Cooper]], and his wife Taya Kyle is portrayed by [[Sienna Miller]].{{cite news|last1=Verrier|first1=Richard|title=Eastwood starts shooting 'American Sniper' at Santa Clarita ranch|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/envelope/cotown/la-et-ct-on-location-american-sniper-20140423-story.html|accessdate=August 5, 2014|work=Los Angeles Times|date=April 23, 2014}} For his portrayal of Kyle, Cooper received an Academy Award nomination for [[Academy Award for Best Actor|Best Actor]], and the film was nominated in five other categories, including [[Academy Award for Best Picture|Best Picture]].{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2015/01/oscar-nominations-2015-full-list-academy-award-nominees-1201350619/|title=Oscar Nominations 2015: Full List Of 87th Academy Award Nominees|first=Patrick|last=Hipes|work=Deadline|date=January 15, 2015|accessdate=January 30, 2015}} The film won the [[Academy Award for Best Sound Editing]].{{cite news |last=Chumley |first=Cheryl K. |title=‘American Sniper’ wins Academy Award — for sound editing |url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2015/feb/23/american-sniper-wins-academy-award-for-sound-editi/ |newspaper=[[The Washington Times]]|date=February 23, 2015 |accessdate=February 23, 2015 }} On February 2, 2015, exactly two years after Kyle's murder, Texas Governor [[Greg Abbott]] declared the day "Chris Kyle Day".{{cite web|last=Holley|first=Peter|date=February 2, 2015|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-nation/wp/2015/01/31/texas-governor-declares-feb-2-chris-kyle-day/|title=Texas Gov. Greg Abbott Declares 'Chris Kyle Day' As 'American Sniper' Continues to Surge|work=The Washington Post|accessdate=February 7, 2015}}{{cite web|agency=Associated Press|date=January 30, 2015|url=http://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2015/01/30/greg-abbott-declares-feb-2-chris-kyle-day|title=Greg Abbott Declares Feb. 2 'Chris Kyle Day'|work=U.S. News & World Report|accessdate=February 7, 2015}}{{cite web|last=Howell|first=Kellan|date=January 30, 2015|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2015/jan/30/greg-abbott-declares-chris-kyle-day-in-texas/|title=Gov. Abbott Declares 'Chris Kyle Day' in Texas: 'We Honor Our Military Heroes'|work=The Washington Times|accessdate=February 7, 2015}} {{Clear}} ==Awards and decorations== The Navy revised Chris Kyle's list of awards on June 14, 2016.{{cite web|title=Kyle DD214 New|url=http://ec.militarytimes.com/static/pdfs/Kyle_dd-214_new.pdf|website=Navy Times|accessdate=July 11, 2016|date=July 8, 2016}} {| style="margin: 1em auto;
